message: Hello Person1. Yep, just got a call for MM/DD/YYYY w Dr. B on MM/DD/YYYY. Re Oxy 15mg rapid release: per Dr. Person2's desire and Dr. B agree to get Person3 off Oxy ext release ASAP, and work down to lowest usage Oxy rapid w/o dealing w break through pain, which can be pretty nasty. I've set up Person3's other am, MM/DD/YYYY, pm meds w 7.5mg Oxy 3x diem, with 7.5 Oxy boosters once, twice a day as needed. Trying to keep Oxy steady at MM/DD/YYYY, but MM/DD/YYYY had to go MM/DD/YYYY. 30 count has gotten him through MM/DD/YYYY, considering ste p down and a few tough pain MM/DD/YYYY thereafter. Re Eliquis: MM/DD/YYYY two 5mg tabs morning and night; MM/DD/YYYY one 5mg am and one 5mg pm. Sig swelling (but improving slightly) swelling of right leg persists. Person3 is tolerating all meds well and following directions. Appetite, a bit of a struggle, as expected; digestion normal (that may become diarrhea as radiation has started MM/DD/YYYY). Dr. B recommends Metamucil 1 tsp 2x diem. Other symptoms: quite tired, napping, MM/DD/YYYY recently interrupted by anxiety attacks. Thanks a ton, Person1, best â€“ Person4

annotations.text: 30 count has gotten him through MM/DD/YYYY, considering ste p down and a few tough pain MM/DD/YYYY thereafter

I was happy to see that this was trending down. We do not have  a comparison for the CEA, but if this serves us value in the future, we will then have something to look back and compare to. Take care, RDL   ----- Message ----- From:  Sent:  To: Subject: RE: Visit Follow-Up Question  Hi Dr Person1, At our last appointment we discussed getting the cancer antigen test at my next blood work. message: Atypical means that cells are not normal but not completely abnormal either - the way Dr Person1 explained it,  there is a spectrum of cells where typical and atypical cells are - so atypical cells can be anywhere on that spectrum past typical. Best thing to do is follow up with ENT, which you are doing. They will keep a clo se eye on it and monitor for changes. Unclear right now to know exactly what it is since the path didn't state cancer directly. Dr Person1 wants you to know that you are doing great! I will keep an eye out for the CT neck results and have Dr Person1 review.

annotations.text: Atypical means that cells are not normal but not completely abnormal either - the way Dr Person1 explained it,  there is a spectrum of cells where typical and atypical cells are - so atypical cells can be anywhere on that spectrum past typical

message: Hello Dr. Person1,    It has been 2 years since my neck surgery and I am still having issues with my eyelid drooping  and the pupil not dilating. You had thought that the surgical clamp may have caused pressure on the nerve sheath and that this would resolve itself and eventually return to normal. Should I still expect that to be the case or would surgery to address the drooping lid be a better option? Appreciate your advice. Thank you,  Person2

annotations.text: You had thought that the surgical clamp may have caused pressure on the nerve sheath and that this would resolve itself and eventually return to normal

message: Hi Person1, I am sorry to hear that this has not recovered. By this point, after two years, it the nerve has not recovered then I think it is unlikely that it will resolve. It is appropriate to consider surgery for the eyelid at this point. I am available to discuss further if you would like. This type of surgery  usually has the best results when done by an oculoplastic surgeon and I can make suggestions if that would be helpful.

annotations.text: By this point, after two years, it the nerve has not recovered then I think it is unlikely that it will resolve

message: Hi Person1, There is always the potential for further nerve recovery, but its also something that we cannot count on at this point. This problem is not a usual risk with this surgery, but in your case the tumor extended behind some of the blood vessels in the neck and was pushing on this nerve. Removing the tumor re quiring pushing on the nerve some to get the tumor out. I will put in a referral for you to see an occuloplastic surgeon.

annotations.text: This problem is not a usual risk with this surgery, but in your case the tumor extended behind some of the blood vessels in the neck and was pushing on this nerve

message: Hi Person1 I discussed with Dr Person2 -  The official recommendations are 6 months after the second dose. But he would advise the third shot now, and would recommend Pfizer or Moderna instead of J/J for the booster. You may get flu like symptoms for a day. Th anks, Person3

message: I need to postpone the appointments made for MM/DD/YYYY, and MM/DD/YYYY for the initial doses of Fulvestrant, that we discussed in your office. I have not completely recovered from the surgery of MM/DD/YYYY. I still have the surgical drain in place, and have a potential appointment tomorrow, MM/DD/YYYY to see Dr  Person2, but it is dependent on fluid accumulation, which I am afraid will not be low enough by then, for removal. Given my history of ulcerative colitis, I am concerned about diarrhea, and I am Very concerned about the Verzenio pill regarding diarrhea. We also could not recall the length of time these therapies would last, nor the potential additional benefit from the addition of the Verzenio. If I encounter an adverse reaction, we were wondering how long it would take to get back to normal after stopping the Fulvestrant and Verzenio. Finally, we were wondering about the additional benefits of these two medications, as compared to Tamoxifen alone which I have tolerated well in the past.
